patterns: Services at home

patterns: X-RAY
What is an X-Ray?
responses: X-rays are a type of radiation that creates pictures of the inside of your body. They are used to diagnose bone fractures, soft tissue abnormalities, lung problems, or for routine checkups.
Call us on our toll-free number: 18002702900

patterns: What are X-rays used for?
What can X-rays diagnose?
responses: X-rays are mainly used to look at bones and joints. They can detect fractures, infections, arthritis, dental decay, bone cancer, and some soft tissue problems like lung issues or internal blockages.
Call us on our toll-free number: 18002702900

patterns: ECG
What is an ECG?
responses: An electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG) is a simple test that records the electrical currents and impulses generated by your heart to check for different heart conditions.
Call us on our toll-free number: 18002702900

patterns: Holter
What is Holter Monitoring?
responses: A Holter monitor is a portable, wearable device used for continuous cardiac monitoring. It records the heart's electrical activity for 24-72 hours to detect abnormalities.
Call us on our toll-free number: 18002702900

patterns: PFT
What is PFT?
responses: A Pulmonary Function Test (PFT) is a lung function test.
Call us on our toll-free number: 18002702900

patterns: are there any risk with xray
Is there any risk with X-rays?
responses: While X-rays are linked to a very slightly increased risk of cancer with high exposure over a lifetime, there is an extremely low risk of short-term side effects from standard diagnostic X-rays. We use low-dose machines.
Call us on our toll-free number for any query: 18002702900

patterns: how much radiation would the patient be facing for the test he is undergoing
How much radiation does a patient face?
responses: The radiation dose is very low, typically between 0.1 to 0.5 mSv for our procedures. For perspective, a single chest X-ray (0.1 mSv) is equal to about 10 days of natural background radiation.
Call us on our toll-free number for any query: 18002702900

patterns: are ecg accurate
Are ECG results accurate?
responses: An ECG is accurate for diagnosing many heart conditions, but it may not pick up every intermittent problem. A normal ECG does not always rule out heart disease.

patterns: what are the limitations of an ecg
What are the limitations of an ECG?
responses: An ECG only records heart rhythm during the few seconds of the test. It may not detect arrhythmias that occur intermittently, requiring longer monitoring.

patterns: how do you prepare a patient for an ecg

responses: Avoid oily skin creams, wear easily removable clothing, and avoid full-length hosiery. No fasting required. Avoid drinking cold water or exercising immediately before the test.

patterns: Audiometry
responses: A hearing test provides an evaluation of the sensitivity of a person's sense of hearing and is most often performed by an audiologist using an audiometer. An audiometer is used to determine a person's hearing sensitivity at different frequencies. Hearing screening is the assessment used to identify a potential hearing deficiency. Hearing screening is therefore conducted when a hearing loss is suspected, to isolate possible hearing loss in newborn children, in first year schoolchildren, or in industrial hearing screening. Pure tone audiometry is the most common choice to evaluate hearing at a number of set frequencies.
Call us on our toll-free number: 18002702900

patterns: do i have xray radiation poisoning
responses: The amount of radiation absorbed by the body — the absorbed dose — determines how sick you'll be. Radiation sickness is also called acute radiation syndrome or radiation poisoning. patterns: what materials show up on xray
responses: X-ray beams pass through your body, and they are absorbed in different amounts depending on the density of the material they pass through. patterns: what is ecg explain its functioning and use
responses: An electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG) is a test that checks how your heart is functioning by measuring the electrical activity of the heart. With each heart beat, an electrical impulse (or wave) travels through your heart. This wave causes the muscle to squeeze and pump blood from the heart.
